name: Galle
fun_fact: Fun fact: Galle Fort is a UNESCO World Heritage Site built by the Portuguese in 1588, then extensively fortified by the Dutch in 1649 - it's the best-preserved European colonial fort in Asia and you can walk the entire rampart at sunset watching cricket on the grounds below!

hero_dishes.name: Galle Fish Curry
hero_dishes.description: Fresh tuna or kingfish curry cooked in coconut milk with goraka (Garcinia cambogia) for sourness
hero_dishes.origin_story: Galle's location on the coast means fish is caught and cooked the same day. The southern Sri Lankan style is distinctly different from the north
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lucky Fort Restaurant, Mama's Galle Fort, beach shacks along Unawatuna

hero_dishes.name: Hoppers (Appa)
hero_dishes.description: Bowl-shaped rice flour pancakes with crispy edges and soft centers, often with an egg in the middle
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Sri Lankan breakfast staple - the batter ferments overnight with coconut milk and toddy
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors in Fort, Pedlar's Inn, traditional cafÃ©s

hero_dishes.name: Lamprais
hero_dishes.description: Rice, meat curry, sambols, and accompaniments wrapped in banana leaf and baked
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Burgher (Dutch-Portuguese descendant) specialty - 'lomprijst' means 'packet of rice' in Dutch. The banana leaf infuses everything with flavor
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Pedlar's Inn, Church Street Social, Sunday markets

hero_dishes.name: Kottu Roti
hero_dishes.description: Chopped roti stir-fried with vegetables, egg, and meat on a hot griddle
hero_dishes.origin_story: The rhythmic clanging of metal scrapers chopping the roti is the sound of Sri Lankan streets at night
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors throughout Galle, busy from 6pm onwards

signature_drinks.name: Ceylon Tea
signature_drinks.description: Sri Lanka is one of the world's top tea producers - the highlands nearby produce exceptional tea
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sweet and milky, often with condensed milk, available everywhere

signature_drinks.name: King Coconut Water
signature_drinks.description: Orange-hued coconuts native to Sri Lanka, incredibly refreshing
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Fresh from the shell, sold by street vendors throughout the fort area

food_culture_notes: Dutch and Portuguese colonial influence visible in architecture AND food
Unawatuna beach nearby is famous for seafood restaurants
Sunday markets sell homemade chutneys, sambols, and curry pastes
Cinnamon is native to Sri Lanka - Galle was a major spice trading port
